newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST - Australian Business News-Feb 17.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST - Australian Business News-Feb 17.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Woodside Petroleum Ltd is set to announce that proven gas reserves will rise more than 60 per cent from 15 trillion cubic feet to 24 tcf, news which underpins the A$6 billion expansion of the North-West Shelf joint venture. The amount in the reserve is enough to lock in vital long-term contracts for liquefied natural gas from Japanese buyers. Page 1.

The announcement of Coca-Cola Amatil's downgrading of its 1996 profit result from double-digit growth to a flat result shattered its market credibility. CC Amatil chief executive Norb Cole says the company's main aim is to recreate the right expectations in the market after the downward spiral in the share price which wiped A$2.6 billion from the company's market capitalisation. Page 17.

Efforts by key telecom and media executives to agree on a new order underpins the success of the A$10 billion Telstra float, the A$4 billion Optus float and about A$10 billion worth of cable-TV and related pay-TV investments. Senior executives from the warring factions are exploring possible ways forward, but personality clashes may endanger the moves. Page 18.

John Fairfax Holdings Ltd chief executive Bob Muscat claims the company is positioned and waiting for an economic upswing, with costs under control and printing problems behind it. Muscat says the company's 24 per cent slump in net profit in the latest interim result was attributable to higher newsprint costs and the continued sluggish economy. Page 18.

The Federal Government's superannuation surcharge legislation has shown extensive deficiencies and shown favouritism for Commonwealth funds for politicians and public servants. Wm Mercer's legislative expert Ray Stevens claim the bills are badly drafted wich makes it difficult to ascertain their meaning. Page 19.

The Australia-Indonesian Timor Gap Joint Authority has authorised and application for the development of the Elang and Kakatua oil fields by oil and gas group Petroz NL and its partners at an estimated cost of A$94 million. The oil fields are located in te ZOCA 91-12 block of the Timor Gap zone of the co-operation (Area A) about 525 kilometres north-west of Darwin. Page 19.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Using two Hyatt Hotels as a base, Singapore's Tuan Sing Holdings Ltd plans to spend up to A$600 million building an Australian hotel chain. Managing director and chief executive officer of the company, David Hwang Soo Chin, says the company is aware the purchase of two hotels does not make a chain, and says the priority is to look at new properties in Sydney and possibly Brisbane. Page 17.

Executives from the biggest banker to telecommunications and entertainment industries worldwide, Chase Manhattan, claim the traditional low risk telecommunications industry is becoming riskier, while the volatile entertainment industry is becoming less riky. The rising number of competitors in the telecommunications industry is making it increasingly unpredictable, while a multiplicity of distribution points has enhanced the value of the entertainment industry. Page 17.

Business Council of Australia president Stan Wallis said yesterday that members of the peak business organisation would confront hard edge issues effecting investment and employment in an attempt to drive a more focussed policy platform. Issues likely to be part of the focus include industrial relations, tax, industry development, technology and possibly native title. Page 17.

Financial services and banking group Colonial's decision to buy out joint Asian venture partner Jardine Pacific Holdings' 50 per cent stake in the joint venture CMG Asia not only doubles its exposure to the revenue upside of the regions emerging economies it increases the company's capital commitment well beyond the A$215 million purchase price. Page 18.

Australia's largest gaming machine manufacturer Aristocrat Leisure Industries Ltd has endured a turbulent initiation to listed life and is yet to convince the investment community that the worst is over, despite the assurances of new executive chairman John Dougall. Page 18.

A BIS Shrapnel report has found retailers rank a product's Australian Made status as a least important attribute when buying small appliances. The survey of 230 retailers found it was the second least important attribute for larger whitegoods, while at the top of both lists was product quality, availability and pricing policies. Page 19
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Perth-based Golden Valley Mines has been tipped to win a share in Indonesia's giant Busang gold deposit, effectively wresting back a minority share in a concession it had sold ahead of the A$40 billion discovery. Page 35.

Comalco's smelting division has informed its workforce that it has abandoned a growth strategy after a six-month review of its long-term plan, the strategy shift follows on from the group's move out of the downstream sector of the business in recent years. Page 35.

The Business Council of Australia has decided to cut its policy focus to a handful of issues in an attempt to revitalise its image and retain influence with the Federal Government. The move will see the council distanced from areas such as mining and manufacturing sector issues and steer clear of bitter issues such as the Century Zinc mine. Page 35.

A directional drilling contractor says it lost A$4 million in costs and lost profits when Telstra allegedly breached a multi-million dollar contract to drill holes for pay TV cables. An A$6 million claim for breach of contract and damages has been lodged under the Trade Practices Act in the Federal Court. Page 37.

Burswood Property Trust has posted an 83.5 per cent increase in interim net profit, with a December half-year profit of A$25.2 million. Despite the profit increase, overall revenue was down 4.3 per cent to A$209.6 million, with a serious decline in Casino revenue because of a fall in the number of so-called Asian junket players. Page 37.

The Federal Government is expected to call for expressions of interest for its 18,000-strong DASfleet in March. No final decision has been made on whether to sell outright or sell and leaseback, where the Government continues to manage and maintain the fleet while financing is done by a third party. Page 37.
THE AGE

Friday's announcement by Federal Treasurer Peter Costello of the axing of the infrastructure bond scheme has threatened the future of up to 10 Victorian infrastructure projects worth more than A$600. The 10 Victorian projects are amongst 75 projects acros Australia worth around A$9 billion in doubt as a result of the concessions removal. Page C1.

Comalco aluminium smelting division has told its workforce of a strategy shift following the groups move out of the downstream sector in recent years and coincides with weak metal prices and strong exchange rates forcing it in to losses. The abandonment of the division's growth strategy came after a six month review of its long-term plans. Page C1.

The future of the Sizzler chain in Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and parts of northern New South Wales is in doubt after the United States-based Sizzler International agreed to let Jardine Matheson close 39 restaurants here. The failure of Jardine Matheson and Collins Foods to agree on terms and price of the sale of the restaurants to Sizzler Inc's wholly owned subsidiary Collins Foods Australia has seen the sale fall through. Page C1.

The Business Council of Australia has decided to cut its policy focus to a handful of issues, leaving the mining or manufacturing industry sectors to lobby in their own territory. The decision is part of an effort to revitalise the Council under the Coalition Government. Page C2.

Former Western Australian Premier Brian Burke will learn today if he has a case to answer on eight charges that he stole A$122, 000 from the Australian Labor Party. The defence submitted last Thursday that Burke had no case to answer after the prosecution closed its case on the sixth day of the trial. Page A2.

Prime Minister John Howard appeared to accept yesterday that native title negotiations on pastoral leases may not conclude before Easter after meeting with New Zealand Prime Minister Jim Bolger on the weekend. Howard has indicated he would like the issue resolved in weeks, not months. Page A2.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
